#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Logan ( Utah )
#Text=Logan
#Text=is a fair-sized town and is growing rapidly , located in the Wasatch Range region of northern Utah .
#Text=The town is home to Utah State University , a state school with approximately 23,000 students .
#Text=Logan offers a wealth of outdoor activities , including some excellent hiking , mountain biking , sport climbing , kayaking , fly-fishing , and skiing .
#Text=Luckily , Logan remains relatively undiscovered , so many of these activities can be experienced in far less crowded conditions than those found in other , similar areas of the US .
#Text=Climate
#Text=Cache Valley has very unpredictable and extreme weather compared to the urban centers of the Wasatch Range .
#Text=Winters are very cold , with daytime temperatures rarely getting above freezing and overnight lows frequently dropping below 0F ( -18C ) .
#Text=Snow is less frequent than in Salt Lake City but the individual storms are usually larger .
#Text=Cache Valley also has one of the worst inversions in the state , in which cold , moist air and pollutants can become trapped in the valley .
#Text=A simple five minute ride up any of the cayons will get you out of the inversion and into some of the most beautiful winter mountain landscapes in all of Utah .
#Text=Spring and Fall are wild and feature frequent temperature changes with possibilities of snow as early as October and as late as May .
#Text=Summer is cooler than in Salt Lake City but still hot , with daytime temperatures generally ranging from 75F ( 24C ) to 95F ( 35C ) - they rarely reach above 100F ( 38C ) .
#Text=It is , however , far enough north that it avoids most of the summer thunderstorms .
#Text=Although the city is cozy and the surrounding terrain is spectacular , the unpredictable weather is a turnoff for some .
#Text=Others find the changing weather enjoyable and enjoy spend time outdoors taking in the many recreactional opportunities throughout the valley and its many canyons .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Drive north on I-15 from Salt Lake City .
#Text=Take exit 362 ( Brigham City ) , and follow US 89/91 through the mountains ( unofficially referred to as Sardine Canyon ) into Cache Valley .
#Text=The drive should take about 75-90 minutes .
#Text=US 89 and 91 split in downtown Logan .
#Text=US 89 heads east through the beautiful Logan Canyon to Bear Lake , a popular tourist destination , while US 91 heads north into Idaho .
#Text=A regional airport also serves Logan although no commercial commuter flights are available at this time .
#Text=Alternately you can also take I-15 N and take Exit 351 for Willard .
#Text=The short UT126 section branches off towards US-89 for Logan and Ogden .
#Text=Keep left at that fork and follow the road till you reach Brigham City and then the right lane will lead you towards Logan .
#Text=This route is 7 miles shorter and a more comfortable drive with very little traffic .
#Text=Get around
#Text=Driving , riding the bus , walking , and cycling are convenient ways to get around town .
#Text=The Cache Valley Transit District ( website : ) bus system serves Logan and surrounding communities with a simple route system that radiates out from the transit center every half hour .
#Text=All buses are equipped to carry two or three bicycles .
#Text=Main Street is heavily used and often congested but parallel streets often provide faster access within Logan .
#Text=Utah State University , on the east side of town , sits on the Provo Bench of ancient Lake Bonneville , about 250 feet higher than downtown Logan .
#Text=This elevation difference is a major deterrent to non-motorized transportation .

#Text=Streets throughout the old grid part of town are wide , thanks to the admonition of Brigham Young to lay out early Utah cities with streets wide enough to turn a double-team of horses and a buck-board around , so there is plenty of room for cyclists .
#Text=See
#Text=Willow Park
#Text=.
#Text=Located in Southwest Logan .
#Text=Willow Park is huge and a great place for picnics or to take the kids .
#Text=It has three different playgrounds and a zoo with a wide variety of species .

#Text=It 's also right next to the Aquatic Center ( the largest public swimming pool in the valley ) , Logan 's only skate park , and the Fairgrounds , where the Fair takes place at the end of every August .
#Text=Logan Canyon
#Text=.
#Text=Located along US 89 northeast of Logan , Logan Canyon is a long , scenic canyon that offers numerous hiking and camping opportunities .
#Text=Tony Grove , near the summit , is among the most popular camping area , and marks the beginning of several trails .
#Text=Beaver Mountain , further up the canyon , is the local ski area .
#Text=Logan Canyon itself is very scenic , and offers spectacular fall colors that rival those of New England .
#Text=During winter , temperatures are excessively cold and the road may be closed at any time due to heavy snow .
#Text=Numerous sinks lie near Logan Canyon , and these areas are popular for snowmobiling .
#Text=The coldest temperature ever recorded in Utah was in Peter 's Sink , near Logan Canyon , a frigid -69째F ( -56째C ) .
#Text=Cave exploring and rock-climbing are also popular activities in Logan Canyon .
#Text=Logan Tabernacle
#Text=.
#Text=Found on Center and Main of downtown Logan , this building and surrounding landscaping is worth a glance .
#Text=A monument heralding Mormon pioneers lies in the northwest corner .
#Text=Check for details on tours .
#Text=Logan Temple
#Text=.
#Text=The second temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints finished in Utah dominates the Cache Valley skyline day and night .
#Text=Well tended gardens and unique architecture are worth a close look .
#Text=Be aware that only members of the church can enter the temple itself .
#Text=Do
#Text=Hiking and mountain biking are very popular in the summer but varied elevation change significantly affects outdoor activity seasons .

#Text=Low , south facing trails like the Wind Caves can often be hiked as early as March , while areas above 9000 ' are usually not hikeable until late June or early July , maintaining broad areas of snow until August .
#Text=Temperature varies with elevation as well , usually temps at 8000 ' are 20F cooler than in Logan , and increasingly colder with elevation gain .
#Text=Summer hail and rain storms are common in high areas when there is no precipitation in Logan .
#Text=Hike the Wind Caves trail .
#Text=2.6 mile round trip , 900 ' elevation gain .
#Text=The trail winds up the north side of Logan Canyon , through maple groves , to a small formation of caves and arches .
#Text=Offers a beautiful view down into the canyon as well .
#Text=Trailhead is ~5 miles up US 89 into Logan Canyon , located on the north side of the road opposite Guinavah-Malibu Campground .
#Text=Hike the Naomi Peak trail .
#Text=5.8 mile round trip , 1980 ' elevation gain . Naomi Peak ( 9980 ' ) is the highest point in the Bear River Range .
#Text=The trail leads through meadows full of wildflowers to the peak , which offers spectacular views of the surrounding peaks and of Cache Valley .
#Text=Trailhead is located at Tony Grove Lake .
#Text=Take US 89 approximately 19 miles up Logan Canyon to the Tony Grove turnoff .
#Text=The lake ( and trailhead ) are 7 miles from US 89 .
#Text=More adventurous and in-shape hikers can access Naomi peak from Cherry Creek near Richmond , UT .
#Text=From Logan drive 13 miles north on US 91 to the town of Richmond .
#Text=Turn right on Main Street , and go straight until reaching 300 East .
#Text=Turn left on 300 E and go straight until the road sort of splits , taking a right onto 500 North .
#Text=The road turns gravel , keep following the gravel road to a parking area , and continue .
#Text=The road after the parking area is dirt and rocky , but accessible by most vehicles in the summer until a river crossing .
#Text=High clearance vehicles should have no problem crossing the river , while hikers in cars can start their hike from the river crossing .
#Text=The trail begins at approx 6000 ' and climbs east past 9765 ' Cherry Peak before crossing a basin leading to Naomi Peak .

#Text=See also Cache Trails , an online copy of a local trail guide ( http://www.logannature.org/cache_trails/canyontrails/ ) , and CacheTrails.org , website for the local trail maintenance organization ( http://www.cachetrails.org/ )
#Text=alternatively you can seek detailed descriptions of Logan 's trail 's here : ( http://www.smallsat.org/travel/logan-hiking-guide.pdf )
#Text=other summer activity 's include rock climbing with many walls available with either lead climbing , top roping or both depending on the wall ,
#Text=notable wall 's include :
#Text=A number of local businesses as well as some in Bear Lake offer snowmobile rentals .

#Text=Logan Canyon has four main parking/trailhead areas for snowmobiles ( Franklin Basin , Beaver Creek , UDOT shed , and " The Sinks " ) and there are a number of other areas to start from including Providence Canyon and Blacksmith Fork Canyon near Hardware Ranch .
#Text=These trailheads offer access to groomed trails , primitive routes , open play areas , and hills .
#Text=Peter Sinks is one of the top ranked snowmobile areas in the country - generally accessed from the Sinks parking area a few miles north .
#Text=Logan Canyon trailheads also offer access to trails leading into the Idaho portion of the Bear River Range , providing an equal array of snowmobile activities .
